docs.snippet: ''CANNERY ROW,'' David S. Ward's screen adaptation of the late John Steinbeck's novellas ''Cannery Row'' and ''Sweet Thursday,'' is the project from which Raquel Welch was sacked early in the production amid a lot of hard feelings. Miss Welch shou...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''CANNERY ROW,'' David S. Ward's screen adaptation of the late John Steinbeck's novellas ''Cannery Row'' and ''Sweet Thursday,'' is the project from which Raquel Welch was sacked early in the production amid a lot of hard feelings. Miss Welch should send a large bouquet of roses to whoever is responsible. The only people who emerge from this precious nonsense smelling good are Richard MacDonald, the English production designer, and Sven Nykvist, the Swedish cameraman. Steinbeck, the 1962 Nobel laureate for literature and the author of more substantial works like ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and ''East of Eden,'' was not always in top form when he devoted himself to the celebration of the all-too-colorful wretches of Cannery Row. These are the softhearted bums, whores, shopkeepers and mental defectives who have dropped out of the American society of the mid-1940's to take up residence in the abandoned sardine canneries, shacks, boilers and pipes on the California coast near Monterey, which Steinbeck sometimes loved too well.

docs.snippet: IT was one of those rare occasions when well-known New Yorkers play second fiddle to the city's less-heralded citizens, and the result Tuesday night at the sixth annual New Yorker for New York Awards was a well-orchestrated evening of dinner, danc...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was one of those rare occasions when well-known New Yorkers play second fiddle to the city's less-heralded citizens, and the result Tuesday night at the sixth annual New Yorker for New York Awards was a well-orchestrated evening of dinner, dancing, speechmaking and camaraderie. The awards were presented by the Citizens Committee for New York City at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to eight New Yorkers, including Beverly Sills, the general director of the New York City Opera, and Philip Johnson, the architect, but equal time for all the award winners was definitely the order of the night. The others honored were: Han Young Lee, the founder of the 600-member Korean-American Parents Council of Flushing, Queens; Irving Cline, president of the Southern Queens Citizens Garden Club, who organized 54 club members to distribute flowers and vegetables to the bedridden elderly; John Sainz and Johnny Rivera, who converted an abandoned East Harlem building into a halfway house for runaways; Haddie Bowers, vice president of the St. John's Place Block Association in Brooklyn, and Pasquale de Martino, who founded the Van Ness Block Association in the Bronx.

headline.main: NEW YORK CITY HONORS EIGHT OF ITS OWN

docs.snippet: Blacks have entered law school and the practice of law in everlarger numbers in the last decade, but most of them have found two of the profession's most lofty perquisites - memberships in school law reviews and partnerships in large law firms - t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Blacks have entered law school and the practice of law in everlarger numbers in the last decade, but most of them have found two of the profession's most lofty perquisites - memberships in school law reviews and partnerships in large law firms - to be elusive. Lenore B. Brown e and Mario L. Baeza, however, have surmounted the high odds. Miss Browne, who is 25 years old, was named this week to The Columbia Law Review, becoming the first black student appointed to the journal since 1968. In law school lore, this is a virtual guarantee of a top-paying job upon graduation. Miss Browne, a native of Roxbury, Mass., was one of four second-year students chosen following a writing competition.

headline.main: 2 BLACKS SURMOUNT ODDS TO ATTAIN ELUSIVE GOALS

docs.snippet: JOHN STEINBECK died in 1968 at the age of 66. Had he lived, he would be celebrating his 80th birthday in a few weeks. The Salinas Valley, where the Nobel Prize-winning novelist was born and raised, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures are celebrating ...
docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN STEINBECK died in 1968 at the age of 66. Had he lived, he would be celebrating his 80th birthday in a few weeks. The Salinas Valley, where the Nobel Prize-winning novelist was born and raised, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures are celebrating it for him. The city of Salinas and M-G-M recently combined for the world premiere of M-G-M's $11.3 million movie, ''Cannery Row,'' starring Nick Nolte and Debra Winger as Steinbeck's whimsical marine biologist and inept hooker. Unlike other major American novelists, Steinbeck had little to complain about in his relationship with Hollywood. If the movie version of his ''Tortilla Flat'' was respectable enough, both ''Of Mice and Men'' and ''The Grapes of Wrath'' were classics, nominated for Academy Awards as best picture, respectively, of 1939 and 1940, with John Ford winning the Oscar as best director for ''The Grapes of Wrath.'' Elia Kazan's 1955 ''East of Eden'' is still memorable for James Dean's portrayal of a tortured adolescent, while a new version of the book has just won a Golden Globe as the best television movie of 1981.

headline.main: HIS HOMETOWN NOW LIKES JOHN STEINBECK BETTER

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Stephen Schlesinger and Stephen Kinzer erroneously contend that ''the most pressing issue'' that led to the overthrow of President Arbenz Guzman ''was Guatemala's seizure of land from the Boston-based United Fruit Company.'' They...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Stephen Schlesinger and Stephen Kinzer erroneously contend that ''the most pressing issue'' that led to the overthrow of President Arbenz Guzman ''was Guatemala's seizure of land from the Boston-based United Fruit Company.'' They also try to link the successful coup d'etat headed by Col. Carlos Castillo Armas with the origins of political violence in Guatemala. Nothing could be more divorced from reality.

headline.main: THE CONFLICTS IN GUATEMALA-PRESENT AND PAST

docs.snippet: The short skirts that are so prominent in the warm weather collections of the Paris couture also turn up in the clothes New York designers have developed for summer. They range from the swingy loose dresses Oscar de la Renta shows in silk crepe, h...
docs.lead_paragraph: The short skirts that are so prominent in the warm weather collections of the Paris couture also turn up in the clothes New York designers have developed for summer. They range from the swingy loose dresses Oscar de la Renta shows in silk crepe, hand painted in colorful swirls and circles suggested by the paintings of So nia Delaunay, to the sporty skinny cotton and linen skirts Bill Blass presents for Blassport. They include brief culottes as well as dresses with divided skirts and run the gamut from day to evening clothes.

docs.snippet: CHRIS CAHILL (Mariel Hemingway) and Tory Skinner (Patrice Donnelly) meet by chance when they are trying out for positions on the women's track team that will represent the United States in the 1976 Olympics. Tory, who is pretty in a skinny, androg...
docs.lead_paragraph: CHRIS CAHILL (Mariel Hemingway) and Tory Skinner (Patrice Donnelly) meet by chance when they are trying out for positions on the women's track team that will represent the United States in the 1976 Olympics. Tory, who is pretty in a skinny, androgynous way, takes one look at the comparatively voluptuous Chris and likes what she sees or, as she says later of Chris, ''She has speed, strength and flexibility - everything I've always wanted.'' Chris, in turn, is enchanted by Tory's expe rience, her firmness of purpose and her performances on the track. On e night, after Chris has suffered food poisoning, Tory takes her h ome, where they relax over some marijuana, watch television, arm wr estle, tickle each otherand then make love.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Dance Theater of Harle m was in a festiv e mood Sunday night, when it presented its Emergence Award to Lena Horne. In on-stage ceremonies at the City Center-55th Street The ater, Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, the company's directors, mad e brief speeches. Then, as the orchestra struck up ''Stormy Weather,' ' Miss Horne entered, and the audience gave her a standing ovation.

headline.main: DANCE: THE HARLEM HAILS LENA HORNE

docs.snippet: B Y yesterday the Big Cold, as it is called by the Chinese, seemed to have loosened its grip on New York, which couldn't have made the city's retailers happier. After suffering extremely weak sales in November and December, many leading retailers ...
docs.lead_paragraph: B Y yesterday the Big Cold, as it is called by the Chinese, seemed to have loosened its grip on New York, which couldn't have made the city's retailers happier. After suffering extremely weak sales in November and December, many leading retailers hoped that post-Christmas business would impove. But it did not and many of them blame the weather. ''Since the second week of January,'' said Geraldine Stutz, president of Henri Bendel, ''business has been an absolute disaster. It was just too cold.''

docs.snippet: The Directors Guild of America has won a resounding victory in an antitrust suit brought against it by Home Box Office, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time Inc.   In July 1978, Home Box Office sued the guild for violating the Sherman Antitrust Act b...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America has won a resounding victory in an antitrust suit brought against it by Home Box Office, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time Inc. In July 1978, Home Box Office sued the guild for violating the Sherman Antitrust Act by refusing to allow its members to work as directors, stage managers or similar categories for Home Box Office until HBO signs a union contract with the guild. In a 77-page opinion released today, Judge Abraham D. Sofaer of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York ruled in favor of the guild.

headline.main: DIRECTORS WIN ANTITRUST SUIT BROUGHT BY HBO
